questions.questionText: What is the difference between weak and strong references?

possibleAnswers.optionText: Strong references increase reference count; weak references do not
Weak references are faster and more memory-efficient
Strong references are used within closures only
No significant difference; both serve the same purpose

possibleAnswers.optionText: To indicate that a closure may outlive the functionâ€™s execution

To enhance closure performance by optimizing execution
To use a closure in multiple threads simultaneously

questions.questionText: What is the difference between frame and bounds in iOS?

possibleAnswers.optionText: Frame is a view's size and position in its superview; bounds is in its own coordinate system
Bounds define animations; frame is for layout positioning
Frame is used for drawing; bounds is for positioning on screen
No difference; frame and bounds are interchangeable

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the 'lazy' keyword in Swift?

possibleAnswers.optionText: To delay property initialization until it is first accessed
To preload data into memory before it is needed
To automatically deallocate unused properties after time
To create static variables shared across class instances

questions.questionText: How does memory management work in iOS?

possibleAnswers.optionText: iOS uses ARC to manage memory by tracking and releasing unused objects
Developers must manually allocate and free memory for objects
Memory is managed by the operating system without developer intervention
Memory management isn't a concern in iOS; modern devices handle it

To create a constant value shared across views within a SwiftUI application

To define view hierarchies and manage UI layout

@Binding is for managing classes; @State is for structs
No significant difference; both can be used interchangeably

questions.questionText: What is the difference between map, flatMap, and compactMap?

possibleAnswers.optionText: map transforms elements; flatMap flattens collections; compactMap removes nils and unwraps optionals
flatMap and compactMap are for optionals; map is for non-optionals
map removes duplicates; flatMap and compactMap handle nested collections
